    • Method Detail

      • notifyMoveOverNode

        public final void notifyMoveOverNode(Id<Link> newLinkId)
        Description copied from interface: DriverAgent
        notifies the agent that it was moved over the node.

        Design thoughts:
        • I find it difficult to see how one should do without this. Somehow the mobsim needs to tell the driver where she is. The mobsim could tell the vehicle, which tells the agent. The DriverAgent would still need this method. kai, nov'11
        • At least in theory, it is possible that a vehicle does not end up on the link where it wanted to go. This is highly improbable if not impossible with the current design, but was easily possible with TRANSIMS, where a vehicle simply may not have been in the correct lane to make a desired turn. kai/michał, mar'17
        Specified by:
        notifyMoveOverNode in interface DriverAgent

      • chooseNextLinkId

        public final Id<Link> chooseNextLinkId()
        Returns the next link the vehicle will drive along.
        Specified by:
        chooseNextLinkId in interface DriverAgent
        Returns:
        The next link the vehicle will drive on, or null if an error has happened.

      • isWantingToArriveOnCurrentLink

        public final boolean isWantingToArriveOnCurrentLink()
        Specified by:
        isWantingToArriveOnCurrentLink in interface DriverAgent

      • resetCaches

        public final void resetCaches()
        Some data of the currently simulated Leg is cached to speed up the simulation. If the Leg changes (for example the Route or the Destination Link), those cached data has to be reseted.

        If the Leg has not changed, calling this method should have no effect on the Results of the Simulation!

      • getId

        public Id<Person> getId()

      • getCurrentLinkId

        public Id<Link> getCurrentLinkId()
        Description copied from interface: NetworkAgent
        Design comments:
        • Agent in many situations knows where he/she is. If not, return null.
        Specified by:
        getCurrentLinkId in interface NetworkAgent
        Returns:
        Id of current link. May be null (e.g. for teleporting agents)

      • getDestinationLinkId

        public Id<Link> getDestinationLinkId()
        Description copied from interface: NetworkAgent
        Design comments:
        • Originally, agents knew where they were going. This was then also used for teleportation. Since then, agents may not know where they are ultimately going. It might thus be more expressive to have "getDestinationLinkId" only for teleporting agents, and have "isArrivingOnCurrentLink" for all others (which would be parallel to how bus passengers handle this). If someone would find this better, and wants to refactor the code, then please go ahead. kai, nov'14
        Specified by:
        getDestinationLinkId in interface NetworkAgent
        Returns:
        Id of destination link. May be null (e.g. for cruising taxi drivers)

      • setVehicle

      • getVehicle

        public MobsimVehicle getVehicle()
        Description copied from interface: VehicleUsingAgent
        Design thoughts:
        • MZ states (in his AdapterAgent) that the DriverAgent should not have this reference. I am, in fact, not so sure (any more); maybe it is not so bad to have this. Clearly, symmetric connectors between objects would be better. kai, nov'11
        Specified by:
        getVehicle in interface VehicleUsingAgent

      • getPlannedVehicleId

        Specified by:
        getPlannedVehicleId in interface VehicleUsingAgent

      • getMode

        public String getMode()
        Description copied from interface: NetworkAgent
        Convenience method for Leg.getMode(), in an attempt to get rid of getCurrentLeg(). If the agent is not on a leg, the behavior of this method is undefined (so don't rely on it).

        Comments:
        • Should be renamed to getLegMode(), in my opinion, as the mode of an agent can be anything else. mrieser/jan'12
        • I don't mind, but my current eclipse can't do the refactoring (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=293861). kai, jan'13
        Specified by:
        getMode in interface NetworkAgent
